entry.title: Transformation Flow, Init and Delta
entry.content:
Hi,
 
1. In my Local Table (Employee Source), I have the Delta Capture option ON.
2. I use this as source table in my Transformation Flow and loaded into target table (Employee Target). I chose to load from table Delta Capture.
3. In the Employee Target table, I can see all records updated correctly, the field Change Type = I, Change Date = Sep 25, 2025, 3:51:01 
4. Now in Local Table (Employee Source), I updated one record only - Employee 123.
5. Run data load again via Transformation Flow, again, all records updated. I can see the Change Date field updated with current run date/time for all the records.
6. Why are all records updated again? I thought it is only Employee 123 will be updated as I chose load from table Delta Capture, not All Active Records??
 
Please advise, thanks.

entry.title: Re: Need Badi/user exit-migo-update batch classification
entry.content: Try with BAdI: MB_DOCUMENT_BADI but please note you will need to use function modules like BAPI_OBJCL_CHANGE or CLAF_CLASSIFICATION_OF_OBJECTS to update classification data or try with BAdI: CL_EX_BATCH_MASTER (or BATCH_MASTER). entry.title: Re: proposal of more than 99 conditions supplement not po...
entry.content:
Why this happens is because, SAP hard-limits the number of condition supplements that can be proposed to 99. Even if you see fewer in the contract, the system may be generating more in the background. Sometimes multiple access sequences, condition records, or overlapping pricing procedures generate supplements you don’t expect. If your pricing procedure or condition type configuration allows multiple supplements, the system may be stacking them up. The contract creation process may trigger condition supplements from multiple sources (e.g., master data, condition tables, or user exits).

To your question "How to replicate in a lower environment", perform the below steps:


  • Copy the same pricing procedure from production into your test system.
  • Create a contract with the same material/vendor/customer combination that triggers the error.
  • Trace pricing:
    • Use Transaction: VKP or Pricing Analysis in the contract.
    • Check which condition types are pulling in supplements.
    • Count how many are being proposed (including hidden/duplicate ones).
  • If you want to stress-test, deliberately create condition records with many supplements (close to 99) and simulate contract creation.

entry.title: Join SAPUI5 Sessions at SAP TechEd 2025
entry.content:
Dear UI5 enthusiasts,

SAP TechEd 2025 is where UI5 developers meet to enhance their knowledge and get hands-on experience. This is the type of content you like to see: Understand the strategy, see highlights and try out latest capabilities around SAPUI5 and SAP Fiori elements.

SAP TechEd in 2025 kicks off on the 4th of November 2025, and preparations are in full swing in SAP. As you probably know, SAP TechEd is the leading tech conference for all developers, IT professionals, business experts, eager to gain in-depth knowledge of SAP’s technologies. It also offers an excellent opportunity to network and connect with peers and SAP experts.

 

SAP TechEd 2025: Registration is live – check out our brand new hybrid experience!

Access the full SAP TechEd 2025 session catalogs:  SAP TechEd Berlin and SAP TechEd Virtual and see my shortlist here:

Keynote

KEY100 | Beyond the hype: How SAP is supercharging developers for what's next
Some experts argue there’s a developer shortage. Others will say developers are no longer needed due to AI. Let’s get real: developers, architects, and technologists are here to stay, and their roles are more important than ever.

Strategy Talks

ST117 | SAP’s user experience strategy with SAP Build
An intuitive user experience is essential for every business user. Examine SAP’s strategy for evolving SAP Build Work Zone to empower a streamlined digital workplace, and for building efficient SAP Fiori apps with SAPUI5. Hear how SAP is advancing with Joule, our AI copilot, now embedded across SAP Build solutions.

ST116 | SAP Build for all: A shift toward AI-assisted developer-centric tools - also available virtually as ST116v
Explore the most recent innovations in SAP Build solutions that help developers to create extensions, applications, and automations. Learn how enhancements in the development environment, SAP Cloud Application Programming Model, and Joule copilot empower customers and partners to build extensions efficiently at scale.

Deep Dives

AD106 | The art and science of SAPUI5 in SAP Build - also available virtually as AD106v
Discover what’s new in SAPUI5 development with SAP Build solutions. Learn to build modern SAP Fiori apps across ABAP and the cloud using new developer tools, Joule technology integration, and proven SAPUI5 capabilities. Get insights into SAP’s UI strategy with SAP Web Components and see how you can benefit. Elevate your UI with SAPUI5 in SAP Build.

AD203 | Fact-checking UI extensibility on cloud and ABAP: What's in it for you
SAPUI5 flexibility lets you extend SAP Fiori apps in a clean core approach. Key users use drag-and-drop tools while developers add custom code with visual editors and the Joule copilot. See how SAP Cloud Application Programming Model and ABAP RESTful application programming model help extend data models and add custom logic in SAP Build solutions.

AD100 | Joule for developers: How AI can boost your development in SAP Build
The Joule for developers add-on combines all the AI capabilities in SAP Build solutions. Learn about AI-driven development and how developer productivity can be increased. Developers can use our productivity tools to make their lives easier when engaging in SAP Cloud Application Programming Model and UI development.

CA105 | Intelligent app development at scale with AI and SAP Fiori elements

With exciting updates to building blocks, a streamlined entry page, and powerful generative AI in SAP Fiori tools, developers can build applications faster than ever. Get a first look at how we integrate MCP to orchestrate AI capabilities across SAP Fiori tools and SAP Fiori elements for faster app development.

AD201 | Explore ABAP Cloud in SAP Build: What's in it for ABAP developers

Understand the importance of our strategic approach of integrating ABAP Cloud into SAP Build solutions. Find out how you can benefit from this for SAP Fiori app development and how the graphical modeler helps you to create ABAP core data services models conveniently. Finally, get insight into our future direction.

Roadmap Sessions

AD818 | Explore the road map for user experience with SAP Build
SAP Build solutions feature many new and upcoming user experience capabilities. Find out how SAP Build Work Zone delivers a connected, intuitive digital workplace, including the SAP Mobile Start app. Understand SAP's road map for building SAP Fiori apps with SAPUI5. See how the Joule copilot supports user and developer productivity.

AD820 | Future of app dev in SAP Build: Simplifying clean core and LoB extensions - also available virtually as AD820v
Check out upcoming enhancements to SAP Build solutions involving SAP’s professional developer tools, the Joule copilot, SAP Cloud Application Programming Model, SAPUI5, and SAP Fiori apps. These updates boost developer productivity, support clean core, and improve extensibility for line-of-business (LoB) apps, advancing enterprise app development.

Hands-on Workshops

AD166 | Taking UI to the next level: Develop SAPUI5 with SAP Build
Use SAP Build solutions to develop a modern app with SAPUI5. Explore latest best practices, including the UI5 linter and TypeScript to build a future-proof app. Get to know SAP Web Components and leverage them in your SAPUI5 app. Gain hands-on experience, ask questions, and see how Joule technology supports you with AI-based SAPUI5 magic.

AD260 | UI extensibility on top of cloud and ABAP: What's in it for you
SAPUI5 flexibility lets you extend SAP Fiori apps with a clean core approach. Key users and developers can add custom code with visual editors and Joule technology. See how SAP Cloud Application Programming Model and the ABAP RESTful application programming model support extending data models and adding custom logic in the SAP Build solution.

AD160 | Get hands-on with Joule: Boost your SAP Build development with AI
The Joule for developers add-on brings AI capabilities directly into SAP Build solutions to support your development process. Get hands-on experience using AI-driven tools to boost your productivity in SAP Cloud Application Programming Model and UI development, with features designed to simplify your workflow and help you build faster and smarter.

Learn how to create new SAP applications with great UX and AI using the reusable components, patterns, and floor plans in SAP Design System. Design with the SAP Fiori for Web UI kit from Figma, harness AI and the MCP protocol for automated app generation and real-time adaptation of SAP Fiori elements, and extend freestyle in SAPUI5.

entry.title: Re: Manage Processing Rules - For Bank Statements
entry.content:
Hi @CGLIT ,

Thank you for your questions. I shall try and answer them. 

As to your 1. question:
If you create a processing rule with the AP/AR Posting action type, then yes: You need to specify in the rule's action (in the Post to AP/AR Account section) who exactly the supplier or customer is by selecting the right account. 
On the other hand, if you select G/L Posting as the action type though, then you can leave the rule's actions empty and the system is going to derive the right G/L account itself in most cases.

As to your 2. question:
If you select Clear in Sequence as the rule's action type, then you can select any available processing instructions. It doesn't necesarily have to be the 010 processing instruction. You can also select any and multiple of the processing instructions described in this help content here: Overview on All Predelivered Processing Instructions
And no, selecting the Clear in Sequence action type does not mean that you need to process the bank statement items manually. You can automate your processing rules so they run in the background and automatically process your bank statement items. For more detailed information see also: 

  • How to Create Processing Rules
  • How to Automate Processing Rules

I hope that info helps. You can also find more information on the SAP Help Portal under Bank Statement Processing.

Best regards,
Anita

entry.title: Re: Please suggest the BAdI name for controlling sales pr...
entry.content: In standard SAP SD pricing, if you enter the same manual condition type (like your ZPR1) multiple times for the same line item, the system will keep all the entries in the pricing screen, but only the last one remains active in the calculation. The earlier ones are flagged as inactive. Still if you want to restrict this, you can try with BAdI to enforce the restriction. The relevant enhancement spot is SD_COND_SAVE_A (Pricing Conditions).

entry.title: Re: Tax Allowance in Depreciation for Malaysia
entry.content:
Hello @S0027169027 ,

Thanks for the question. Below is a list of what is available in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition and the requirements of Malaysia’s regulations.

In the Public Cloud, depreciation keys come pre-set. You won’t be able to create or freely adjust a key to perfectly match 20% Initial Allowance in the first year and then 10% Annual Allowance afterwards. SAP Help Portal-Depreciation Key

Depreciation area 15 – Local Tax is used to hold tax values, but it depends on the specific keys and methods provided. There does not seem to be publicly available evidence of a Malaysia key matching the 20/10 pattern out of the box. SAP Help Portal-Depreciation Areas

Malaysia’s capital allowance regime generally allows for an initial 20% deduction in the first year, followed by an additional 10–20% often around 10% for specific classes. Remember, this is related to taxes, not the depreciation shown in books. PwC Tax Summaries

Let me know if you need further support

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Principal Propagation Setup for HTTPS and RFC (SNC) Protocol from SAP BTP to S/4HANA
entry.content:
Principal Propagation Setup for HTTPS and RFC (SNC) Protocol from SAP BTP to S/4HANA

In this blog, we'll walk through how to configure Principal Propagation from SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) to an on-premises S/4HANA system, using SAP Cloud Connector and SAP Web Dispatcher. We are configuring principal propagation to an S/4HANA system for HTTPS communication and RFC communication using SNC.

References

  • https://help.sap.com/docs/connectivity/sap-btp-connectivity-cf/configuring-principal-propagation

About

Principal propagation is the secure process of forwarding a cloud user's identity from a cloud environment to an on-premise system, enabling single sign-on (SSO) and ensuring the user's personal authorizations apply. It relies on a trusted relationship between the cloud and on-premises systems, using mechanisms like JSON Web Tokens (JWTs) or certificates to pass the user's context unchanged, allowing the backend system to recognize the individual user and their permissions.

Scenario: Cloud to On-Premises

  1. A user logs in to the cloud application. Its identity is established by an identity provider (this can be the default IdP for the subaccount or another trusted IdP).
  2. The cloud application then uses a user exchange token (or a designated secondary header) to propagate the user to the Connectivity service. Optionally, the application may use the Destination service to externalize the connection configuration that points to the target on-premise system.
  3. The Connectivity service forwards the JWT (that represents the user) to the Cloud Connector.
  4. The Cloud Connector receives the JWT, verifies it, extracts the attributes, and uses its STS (security token service) component to issue a new token (for example, an X.509 certificate) with the same or similar attributes to assert the identity to the backend (BE1-BEm). The Cloud Connector and the cloud application share the same trust settings.
  5. The Cloud Connector sends the new token (for example, an X.509 certificate) to the backend system.

Pre-requisite

  • Ensure that the SAP Cloud Connector (SCC) is installed and its initial setup has been completed. Refer to the SAP Help documentation.
  • The Cloud Connector should be connected to your SAP BTP subaccount by adding the subaccount details within the SCC. Refer to the SAP Help documentation
  • Additionally, trust must be established between your subaccount and the SAP Cloud Identity Services tenant. This trust setup allows integration with any corporate identity provider and is essential for enabling Single Sign-On (SSO) in your cloud application. Refer to the SAP Help documentation

Configuration Steps

StepsAction Items
1Configure Principal Propagation to an ABAP System for HTTPS
1.1Generate Certificates in SAP Cloud Connector (SCC)
1.2Add Certificates to the SCC Trust Store
1.3Synchronize the cloud trust with Subaccount IDP
1.4Configure SAP S/4HANA for Principal Propagation (HTTPS)
2Configure SAP Web Dispatcher for Principal Propagation
2.1Import Certificates into SAP Web Dispatcher
2.2Maintain Required Parameters in Web Dispatcher
3Configure Principal Propagation to an ABAP System for RFC using SNC
3.1PSE Setup in SAP Cloud Connector for SNC
3.2Configure the S/4HANA System for RFC SNC Propagation
4Create System Mappings in SAP Cloud Connector
4.1Map HTTPS Connections to SAP Web Dispatcher
4.2Map RFC SNC Connections to S/4HANA Backend
5Create Destination in SAP BTP subaccount for HTTPS and RFC SNC scenario

Step 1: Configure Principal Propagation to an ABAP System for HTTPS

Step 1.1: Generate Certificates in SAP Cloud Connector (SCC)

We must configure the following certificates in Cloud Connector:

  • System Certificate
  • CA Certificate
  • User Certificate (Subject Pattern for Principal Propagation)

Note: It is recommended to use signed certificates. Self-signed certificates will also work.

Generating System Certificate

To configure the System Certificate, go to Configuration → On Premise → System Certificate → Create and import a self-signed certificate. Fill the required details in the pop-up window. The Common Name (CN) represents the server’s name protected by the SSL certificate.

Generating CA Certificate

A CA certificate signs all the certificates that are used when a request is forwarded from the Cloud with the Cloud principals.

To create the CA certificate, scroll down to the corresponding section and click on the “Create and import a self-signed certificate” button.

Generating User Certificate

This sample certificate is used to define the rules in the S/4HANA system under the Transaction code (CERTRULE).

Scroll down to the principal propagation section and edit the Subject Pattern Select the Subject Pattern from the list to assert the user IDs. For example, select ${email} to assert the user against the user’s mail address propagated from the Cloud.

click on the Create Sample Certificate button.

Choose an email that already exists on the backend system. Please remember that this is only a sample certificate and will be used to create a rule-based mapping on the backend AS ABAP system

Step 1.2: Add Certificates to the SCC Trust Store

In trust store add below certificates

  • S4HANA SSL server standard
  • Web dispatcher server certificate

Step 1.3: Synchronize the cloud trust with Subaccount IDP

By default, the Cloud Connector does not trust any entries which issues tokens for principal propagation. For this reason, we must establish the trust between the Cloud Connector and the IDP of your subaccount on BTP.

Navigate to the “Cloud to On-Premise” and select the tab Principal Propagation. Click on Synchronise this populate the trust configuration.

Step 1.4: Configure SAP S/4HANA for Principal Propagation (HTTPS)

Now we will do the required configuration in ABAP system.

Step 1.4.a: Import Certificates into the ABAP SSL Server Standard (Transaction: STRUST)

Below certificates need to be imported.

  • cloud connector system certificate imported in s4hana ssl server standard
  • web dispatcher client certificate imported in s4hana ssl server standard

Step 1.4.b: Define Rule-Based Mapping with User Certificate (Transaction: CERTRULE)

Click on the “Import Certificate” button to import the User certificate that was downloaded from the Cloud Connector. In the “Certificate Attr.” choose you attribute mapping from the drop-down menu. In the “Login As” select E-Mail and press enter.

Once you save your new rule you should see a similar screen as below where the “Mapping Status” and “User Status” are both green.

Step 1.4.c: Maintain Reverse Proxy and other parameters in the Default Profile (Transaction: RZ10)

Copy Subject and issuer values from web dispatcher client certificate and Cloud Connector System Certificate

For following parameter: icm/trusted_reverse_proxy_<x> = SUBJECT="<subject>", ISSUER="<issuer>".

  • Select a free index for <x>.
  • <subject> is the subject of the certificate (example data: CN=SCC, OU=BTP Scenarios, O=Trust Community, C=DE).
  • <issuer> is the issuer of the certificate (example data: CN=MyCompany CA, O=Trust Community, C=DE).

Example: icm/trusted_reverse_proxy_2 = SUBJECT="CN=SCC, OU=BTP Scenarios, O=Trust Community, C=DE", ISSUER="CN=MyCompany CA, O=Trust Community, C=DE".

Parameter name

Value

icm/trusted_reverse_proxy_0

Copy subject and issuer values from web dispatcher client certificate

icm/trusted_reverse_proxy_1

Copy subject and issuer values from cloud connector system certificate

login/certificate_mapping_rulebased

1

icm/HTTPS/verify_client

1

Step 1.4.d: Set Logon Procedure to “Required with SSL Certificate” for Relevant SICF Services

To access ICF services via certificate logon, make sure that all required ICF services allow Logon Through SSL Certificate as logon method.

Step 2: Configure SAP Web Dispatcher for Principal Propagation

If you are using an intermediate SAP Web Dispatcher to connect to your ABAP backend system, you must set up a trust chain between the involved components Cloud Connector, SAP Web Dispatcher, and ABAP backend system.

We need to Configure SAP Web Dispatcher to trust the Cloud Connector's certificate for identity propagation. Parameters and certificates need to be added.

Make sure your SAP Web Dispatcher supports SSL and configuration done for Web Dispatcher to Forward SSL Certificates for X.509 Authentication. Refer SAP Help documentation for pre-requisites.

Step 2.1: Import Certificates into SAP Web Dispatcher

Below Certificates to be added in web dispatcher PSEs.

  • cloud connector CA certificate in web dispatcher server standard pse (SAPSSLS.pse )
  • s4hana ssl server standard certificate in web dispatcher client pse (SAPSSLC.pse)

Step 2.2: Maintain Required Parameters in Web Dispatcher

Create icm trusted reverse proxy parameters same as we did in Step 1.4.c

Parameter name

Value

icm/trusted_reverse_proxy_0

Copy subject and issuer values from cloud connector CA certificate

icm/trusted_reverse_proxy_1

Copy subject and issuer values from s4hana ssl server standard certificate

Make sure icm/HTTPS/verify_client parameter is set to 1 (request certificate) or 2 (require certificate). If set to 0, trust cannot be established. The default value is 1, so it is OK if the parameter is not set at all.

Your HTTPS Principal Propagation configuration is now complete for the scenario where a Web Dispatcher is used as an intermediary between the ABAP backend system.

Step 3: Configure Principal Propagation to an ABAP System for RFC using SNC

For enabling Principal Propagation over RFC using Secure Network Communication (SNC), follow the steps below.
If you've already configured HTTPS-based principal propagation on the same S/4HANA system, steps such as certificate generation, trust setup, and user mapping (via STRUST and CERTRULE) may have already been completed. You only need to ensure the SNC-specific configurations.

Make sure SNC setup on the ABAP System is already present. Ensure SAP Cryptographic library is installed as a pre-requisite in cloud connector.

Note: It is important that you use the same SNC implementation on both communication sides. When using the SAP Cryptographic Library, it is recommended that you use an ABAP system SNC identity and a Cloud Connector system identity signed by the same CA for mutual authentication.

Step 3.1: PSE Setup in SAP Cloud Connector for SNC

Step 3.1.a: Login to OS level of SCC then Download and extract the SAP Cryptographic Library. You can refer SAP Help documentation.
Step 3.1.b: Ensure you have set the Environment variables SECUDIR and SNC_LIB

Step 3.1.c: Create SNC PSE at OS level. Navigate to path Crypto and execute below commands

You can Refer SAP Help documentation and below note.

2642538 - How to enable SNC from external programs to ABAP using SAP RFC Connectors

To Create SNC PSE: sapgenpse gen_pse -p SCC.pse "CN=SCC, OU=<name>, O=<name>, C=<name>"

It is recommended that you sign the CSR of PSE with a trusted CA and then import it. Self-signed will also work.

Import Signed Certificate: sapgenpse import_own_cert -p SCC.pse -x <pin> -c SCC.cer -r <RootCA>.cer

Create credentials for the SNC PSE: sapgenpse seclogin -p SCC.pse -O <sccuser>

Note: sccuser is the user under which cloud connector is running.

Adding ABAP SNC certificate in Cloud connector PSE (download from S/4HANA, STRUST --> SNC): sapgenpse maintain_pk -p SCC.pse -a S4HANA.cer

Step 3.1.d: Restart Cloud connector below SNC SECUDIR parameter will appear in Cloud connector UI Configuration tab. (Library path and My name details we need to give).

Once you have created the SNC PSE and imported the required certificates into it, take restart and login to cloud connector UI to define the SNC name

Step 3.2: Generate Certificates in Cloud Connector

(This step is identical to the HTTPS scenario Step1.1. You may skip it if the certificates were already generated during the HTTPS setup.)

Step 3.3: Add Certificates to the Trust Store in SCC

(This step is identical to the HTTPS scenario Step 1.2. S4hana SSL server standard certificate needs to be added.)

Step 3.4: Synchronize Cloud Trust with Subaccount Identity Provider (IdP)

(This step is identical to the HTTPS scenario Step 1.3. You can skip this step if already done.)

Step 3.5: Configure the S/4HANA System for RFC SNC Propagation

Step 3.5.a: Import Certificates into the SSL Server Standard (Transaction: STRUST)

Below certificates needs to be added.

  • cloud connector system certificate imported in S/4HANA SSL server standard
  • cloud connector PSE SNC certificate imported in S/4HANA SNC cryptolib
Step 3.5.b: Define Rule-Based Mapping for the user certificate (Transaction: CERTRULE)

(This step is identical to the HTTPS scenario Step 1.4.b. You can skip this step if user mapping has already been configured and login/certificate_mapping_rulebased parameter set to 1)

Step 3.5.c: Configure SNC Identity in the backend system (Transaction: SNC0)

Login to backend ABAP system and execute transaction SNC0 and add cloud connector’s SNC identity. Note the SNC name from SAP Cloud connector.

Step 4: Create System Mappings in SAP Cloud Connector

We need to create Mapping Virtual To Internal System in the Cloud To On-Premise tab for your subaccount in Cloud connector.

Step 4.1: Map HTTPS Connections to SAP Web Dispatcher

Since we are using a Web Dispatcher as an intermediary to the ABAP backend system, we will define the Web Dispatcher host in the HTTPS destination configuration instead of the ABAP system directly. The flow will be like this.

BTP (Service) --> cloud connector --> web dispatcher --> S/4HANA

Parameter

Value

Backendtype

Other SAP system

Protocol

HTTPS

Internal Host

Host of the web dispatcher

Internal Port

Port of the web dispatcher

Virtual Host

Enter any value but avoid underscores in the name.
Note: Remember your entry as you need it to configure the destination in your SAP BTP subaccount.

Virtual Port

Enter any numerical value.
Note: Remember your entry as you need it to configure the destination in your SAP BTP subaccount.

Principal Type

X.509 Certificate (General Usage)

Host In Request Header

Use Internal Host

Select the mapping you just created and add the Resources as per your requirement.

URL Path

Access Policy

/

Path and All Sub-Paths

Step 4.2: Map RFC SNC Connections to S/4HANA Backend

Parameter

Value

Backend-type

ABAP System

Protocol

RFC SNC

Application Server

host for the S/4 HANA backend services

Instance Number

Instance number of the S/4 HANA backend

Virtual Application Server

Enter any value but avoid underscores in the name.
Note: Remember your entry as you need it to configure the destination in your SAP BTP subaccount.

Virtual Instance Number

Enter any numerical value.
Note: Remember your entry as you need it to configure the destination in your SAP BTP subaccount.

Principal Type

X.509 Certificate (General Usage)

SNC Partner Name

ABAP system's SNC identity name (for example, p:CN=SID, O=Trust Community, C=DE). Copy from profile parameter snc/identity/as

Select the mapping you just created and add the Resources as per your requirement.

entry.title: SAP Community Hobbies series: Don't fly blind (Stress to strength: Mindful living in work & beyond)
entry.content:
Thanks to Moshe

First of all, a heartfelt thank you to  @moshenaveh , who initiated this wonderful blog series about hobbies in the SAP Community. His post “Mind your step” about walking and hiking not only inspired me, but also showed me how closely movement, nature, and inner peace are connected. Hiking and running have also been passions of mine for many years. But one special experience led me onto a new path: the path of yoga. Today I combine both movement in nature and on the yoga mat, combined with mindfulness, conscious breathing, and inner clarity.

Me on a mindful hike near Austria wearing a hat.

Who I am

My name is Achim Toeper, and I have been part of the SAP world for more than three decades. My professional journey has taken me deep into technology and leadership – but at the same time I discovered another passion: yoga and mindfulness. Since completing my yoga teacher training in 2018, these practices have become an integral part of my life. They give me energy, inspiration, and a new way of engaging with people in projects, teams, and communities. From this connection, personal projects where born, in which I combine movement, mindfulness, and leadership skills, like writing and talking about it.

My path to yoga

Some years ago, I found myself in an extremely intense professional period, marked by great responsibility and pressure. The stress kept growing – and I realized that I needed a counterbalance to avoid burning out. In this search, I came across yoga for the first time in a wellness hotel in the Allgäu – at exactly the moment when I needed it the most. This experience truly flashed me: I immediately felt that yoga is more than just movement. During those very days, I knew I wanted to dive deeper and one day become a yoga teacher myself. Step by step I learned how to regain strength through conscious breathing, movement, and meditation. Yoga gave me not only calm and balance, but also a new perspective on leadership, collaboration, and on myself.

Yoga class and ice bathing in the Ore Mountains 2014

A special moment in Copenhagen

Since that first encounter, yoga has become a constant part of my life. In 2018 I had the opportunity to bring my passion into a very special setting at the SAP Community Event in Copenhagen. At the end of my talk, I sat down cross-legged on stage while the audience remained in their seats. Behind me, an animated GIF was running in my presentation, visualizing the rhythm of box breathing:
inhale for four seconds, hold for four seconds, exhale for four seconds, hold for four seconds.
Together we followed this rhythm – and for a moment the large conference room became completely silent. Everyone was connected through the same breathing pattern. This experience was surprising for many and deeply moving for me: a moment where technology, community, and mindfulness came together in a very powerful way. 



A special honor for me on World Mental Health Day

Another highlight was October 10th 2023, the international World Mental Health Day. On this day, I was invited to lead an international yoga session for my company. People from different countries and time zones came together virtually to breathe, move, and pause for a moment. For me it was a great honor and at the same time a confirmation that mindfulness and yoga go far beyond private practice – they can build bridges, create community, and have a tangible impact in a global professional environment.

What yoga means to me

For me, yoga is far more than physical exercises. It is an attitude that shapes everyday life – both professionally and personally. It reminds me that behind every role and function there is always a human being. This perspective has changed my leadership style: away from pure control, towards more trust, calmness, and leading by example. In my company, some colleagues jokingly call me “Yoda” – a nice sign that mindfulness not only brings calm but also inspiration. For me, yoga is a compass that helps me stay clear, human, and connected even in challenging situations.

Practicing Vrksasana Yoga “Tree Pose” on a hike.

Running, swimming, and the strength of connecting with others

Back in 2000, I joined a group mainly consisting of triathletes and hockey players. That was the moment I finally started running – something I had enjoyed before but never really practiced regularly.
My last major run was in 2014 in Vienna, a city that holds a special place in my heart.

Last year – as well as this year – I completed an Olympic triathlon. Swimming has always had a calming effect on me, running grounds me in the here and now, and the combination of all three disciplines teaches me perseverance, humility, and trust in my own body.

I remember well the SAP Community Event in Copenhagen in May 2018 – that’s where I met @smarchesini .
Sebastiano is not only someone who drives SAP topics forward, but also someone who shares his passion for running with others.
I am delighted that he will be next in this hobbies series – because running connects us, and I am sure his story will bring fresh inspiration.

Photo of me taken during a race at a multi-generational run

Join the conversation

Do you do Yoga or Meditation? Share the pictures and stories behind them in the comments section. Feel free to share other hobbies you have!

If you're interested in joining the series, please reach out to Moshe Naveh via community@sap.com.

Let's get this journey going! I hope you all enjoy the great posts coming-up!

entry.title: Re: Dive into the future of SAP Universal ID and understand the changes underway
entry.content:
Dear Community Members,

Thank you for sharing your feedback and concerns with us.

The primary change is that SAP Universal ID will no longer function as an identity provider. This modification to the login process is a crucial component of a broader initiative aimed at streamlining user management. It also serves as a technical foundation that will eventually allow customers to integrate their own corporate identity providers seamlessly.

Other substantial features of SAP Universal ID will stay: Your SAP Universal ID continues to serve as a wallet for managing your user identities. It ensures lifelong access to your account and preserves your reputation such as learning certificates and community content.

We apologize for the temporary inconvenience caused by the need to manage multiple user identities and manually switch between them due to the recent changes. SAP is currently developing an account switcher functionality to alleviate this issue.

Once the new functionality is implemented, you will log in using your S/P-user or the associated email address. After logging in, the system will display all user identities (S/P-users) linked to your UID. You can then switch to another user identity by clicking on it and entering the associated password.

For more information about future developments in authentication for digital platforms, you can refer to this News Article and YouTube interview.

To bring up improvement requests directly, join our SAP Continuous Influence session to share detailed ideas and requirements on bring your own identity, S-user management, and SAP Universal ID, ensuring clarity and effective review by SAP (an S-user is required to submit improvement requests).

entry.title: Re: How to consume APIs in custom RAP application for SAP...
entry.content:
Hello,
Thank you very much for your question. Can you please check whether the following information (GenAI was used to help generate this content) answers your questions:

To consume an external API in a RAP application within the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud environment, follow these steps:

  1. Identify the External API: Determine the API you need to consume and understand its specifications, including endpoints, authentication methods, and data formats.

  2. Create a Communication Scenario: Set up a communication scenario in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Creating Custom APIs in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public … - SAP Community Extensibility in SAP S/4HANA Cloud - SAP Community to enable external communication. This involves defining the API endpoints and authentication details.

  3. Develop the RAP Application:

    • Define the Data Model: Use Core Data Services (CDS) to define the data model that will interact with the external API.
    • Implement Business Logic: Create ABAP classes to handle the API requests and responses. Use ABAP Development Tools (ADT) in Eclipse to write the necessary code.
    • Expose as OData Service: Define a service definition and service binding to expose the data model as an OData service.

  4. Test the Integration: Use tools like Postman to test the API integration and ensure that the RAP application correctly consumes and processes the external API data.

Best Practices and Configurations

  • Security: Ensure secure communication by using HTTPS and appropriate authentication methods like OAuth.
  • Error Handling: Implement robust error handling in your ABAP classes to manage API failures gracefully.
  • Performance Optimization: Optimize API calls to reduce latency and improve the application’s performance.

Sample Code Snippet

Here is a basic example of how you might structure the ABAP code to consume an external API:

CLASS zcl_external_api_handler DEFINITION
  PUBLIC
  CREATE PUBLIC .

  PUBLIC SECTION.
    INTERFACES if_http_service_extension .

  PROTECTED SECTION.
  PRIVATE SECTION.
    DATA: lt_response TYPE string.
ENDCLASS.

CLASS zcl_external_api_handler IMPLEMENTATION.

  METHOD if_http_service_extension~handle_request.
    DATA(lv_req_body) = request->get_text( ).
    " Call external API and process response
    CALL METHOD me->consume_external_api
      EXPORTING
        iv_request_body = lv_req_body
      IMPORTING
        ev_response_body = lt_response.
    response->set_text( lt_response ).
  ENDMETHOD.

  METHOD consume_external_api.
    " Implement API consumption logic here
  ENDMETHOD.

ENDCLASS.

Additional Resources

For more detailed guidance, you can refer to the SAP Extensibility Explorer for examples and tutorials on different types of extensibility available in S/4HANA Cloud.

[1] Creating Custom APIs in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public ... - SAP Community
[2] Extensibility in SAP S/4HANA Cloud - SAP Community

Kind regards,

Henrike

entry.title: Re: #CoE#OTMC Zscaler and SAP Router
entry.content:
Hello,

Thank you very much for your question.

Please check whether the following information (GenAI was used to help generate this content.) is useful.

Migrating SAP Router to an Azure Virtual Machine protected by Zscaler involves several considerations, especially regarding the compatibility of SAP’s private protocols with Zscaler’s Zero-Trust policies.

Key Considerations:

  1. SAP Router Functionality:

    • SAP Router is a crucial component for managing remote connections between SAP systems and clients like SAPGUI. It uses proprietary protocols for authentication and communication.

  2. Zscaler Integration:

    • Zscaler provides a cloud-based security platform that enforces Zero-Trust policies, which might affect how SAP Router communicates with SAPGUI.
    • Zscaler Private Access (ZPA) can potentially replace SAP Router by providing secure access to internal applications without the need for a VPN.

  3. Compatibility and Configuration:

    • Ensure that Zscaler’s policies allow the necessary SAP protocols to pass through without interference.
    • You may need to configure Zscaler to recognize and allow SAP Router’s traffic, ensuring that authentication and data integrity are maintained.

  4. Testing and Validation:

    • Conduct thorough testing to ensure that SAPGUI can still connect seamlessly through SAP Router when protected by Zscaler.
    • Validate that all security policies are correctly applied and do not disrupt SAP Router’s functionality.

Recommendations:

  • Consult with SAP and Zscaler Support: Engage with both SAP and Zscaler support teams to understand the best practices for integrating SAP Router with Zscaler.
  • Pilot Testing: Before full migration, conduct pilot tests to identify any potential issues and ensure smooth operation.
  • Documentation and Training: Ensure that your technical team is well-informed about the changes and trained on managing the new setup.

While there is limited information available online about this specific integration, these steps should help guide you through the process. If you have further questions, consulting with experts who have experience in SAP and Zscaler integration might be beneficial.

Kind regards,

Henrike

entry.title: Re: Does SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Support OCR-based Invoi...
entry.content:
Good day @byd 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at Supplier Invoice Processing, Overview of SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management & Invoice List Partner for more details.

In summary, there is currently no built-in OCR capability to scan and capture supplier invoices from PDF or paper format directly into the system in the public cloud. Standard supplier invoice processing is available in the Fiori apps (such as Create Supplier Invoice, Create Supplier Invoice- Advanced), and electronic invoice can be integrated through APIs and interfaces.

If you require OCR invoice capture, the recommended approach from SAP is for you to use SAP central Invoice Management which integrates with SAP Business Network. This solution provides scanning, OCR machine learning-based extraction of invoice data. Please note that this requires additional licensing.

Alternatively, you can integrate a third-party OCR solution from SAP Store. This will enable you feed invoice data into the public cloud through SAP Integration Suite.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Understanding the importance of legacy bonus plan eligibility rules in Variable Pay
entry.content:
Introdution

In this blog we look at the importance of legacy bonus plan eligibility rules in Variable Pay. We can turn them on with the following checkboxes:

 

They are the only ones that will work both for EC records and Imported (non-EC) records (EC bonus plan rules only work for EC imported records) and as such are critical to handle the following scenarios:

  • Case of permanently transferred employees (for example 1/1 to 3/31 employee of the Peru legal entity then 4/1 to 9/1 employee of the Canada legal entity and since 9/2 employee of the US legal entity) where customer needs to export the data for the different userID retrieved from EC and load it under the ID of the latest active record in order for the full payout to show up on the statement of the most current active record of the employee.
  • Case of EC data missing for the first cycle (for example bonus cycle is 1/1 to 12/31 and EC data cutover was 9/1 so two third of the fiscal year data of reference is missing in EC and needs to be imported in the VarPay template's Employee History.

What is supported and not supported in legacy rules based on the few information I was able to gather and most importantly based on my own testing in my demo environment:

  • SUPPORTED : OR conditions
  • SUPPORTED : OR + AND conditions
  • NOT SUPPORTED : > or < conditions on decimal fields

 

How to handle simple OR conditions in legacy bonus plan rules

 

How to handle complex OR + AND conditions in legacy bonus plan rules

 

How to handle more complex cases ?

entry.title: Automating Custom Performance Data Transfer to Employee Profiles
entry.content:
Automating Custom Performance Data Transfer to Employee Profiles

At SAP SuccessFactors, dynamic employee profile is the heart of a successful Human Experience Management (HXM) strategy.  If your client wants to transfer critical information from Performance Form to Employee Profile through seamless user interface, this is possible.

Performance Form

Consider a scenario within SuccessFactors, a manager completes a Performance Management Form, that includes custom section – with Field 1, Field 2, Field 3.  This data needs to be pushed to Employee Profile – Background element.

Employee profile

The Employee Profile in SAP SuccessFactors is a centralized repository that captures employee skills, experiences, education, and career preferences, supporting talent management, succession planning, and development initiatives across organization.

Here, we have a Background element configured that includes Field 1, Field 2, Field 3.

Screenshot added below for reference.

  

Technical Diagram

The technical diagram below illustrates the integration flow built using SAP BTP Integration Suite to enable data exchange between Performance Form custom fields and the Employee Profile background element. It outlines the key steps involved, including API calls, data transformation, and posting using OData APIs. This setup leverages cloud integration capabilities to ensure smooth and automated data transfer between the two SuccessFactors modules.

 Technical specifications

Leveraging the Cloud Integration capability of Integration Suite service on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) you can easily connect various data elements to exchange data. We will be doing the same over here to exchange data between Performance Form custom fields and Employee Profile – background element. In the process we will be using the below listed APIs and entities –

  1. URL of background element API- SAP Business Accelerator Hub
  2. API type – ODATA
  3. Authentication - Basic
  4. Entity – EPCustomBackgroundPortlet
  5. Endpoint – /EPCustomBackgroundPortlet
  6. Method – POST

 

  1. URL of performance form API – SAP Business Accelerator Hub
  2. API type – ODATA
  3. Authentication - Basic
  4. Entity – FormCustomSection
  5. Endpoint- /FormCustomSection
  6. Method - GET

Process

 

Below listed are the steps that you need to follow to attain the objective-

  • Step 0: Login to Integration Suite and create an I-flow.
  • Step 1- GET Data: Create a GET call to retrieve data from the performance form using the above listed API. Various filters and select queries can also be used while retrieving the data. (/FormCustomSection).

  • Step 2- Content modifier: Store the data in content modifier.

  • Step 3 – JSON to XML converter: Convert the JSON payload to XML
  • Step 4 – Filter: Filter the XML payload for the fields which are required to be passed to employee profile

  • Step 5 – XML to JSON converter: Convert the filtered payload back to JSON
  • Step 6 – Content modifier: Store the filtered payload
  • Step 7 – POST data: Post the data to employee profile form using the above listed API  (/EPCustomBackgroundPortlet)

Conclusion:
Automating the transfer of custom performance data to employee profiles in SAP SuccessFactors enhances data accuracy and streamlines talent management. By leveraging SAP BTP’s Integration Suite and OData APIs, organizations can ensure seamless, efficient, and scalable synchronization between performance forms and employee profile.

Thankyou!

entry.title: ENGINEERING CHANGE MANAGEMENT(ECM)
entry.content:
Engineering change Management(ECM):

ECM  is used to keep track of changes to master data and also control those changes to master data, so that only those with authorisation can make the change. we can maintain history with all the changes done with respect to change number.

STEPS FOR CREATION AND USING ECM:

  go to cc01 transaction code and click on enter as it ECN is internal number here

Cc01

 

Enter description ,valid date and change number status should be active(01)

         

next click on object types and new screen will open here we can select which master data we want to keep track on ,select BOM, Task list by selecting the  first three tick marks

 

now click on save

ECN number 500000000000 got created now if you make any changes to BOM or routing pass the ECN number or make ECN  manadatory for changes to BOM and routing

 

to test the changes 

now go to CA02 and pass ECN also with material details

 

 

there is no description for operation i am adding it and saving it

 

to check the changes made go to cc02 and pass the ECN number

 

then go to environment and then to reporting and then to tasklist

 

now we can see the history of all master data changes made with this particular ECN

 

CONCLUSION: Engineering change management helps us to track the changes made to Master data(BOM, Routing etc),Which helps in accountability and identifying changes done to that particular data. we can even restrict the users from doing changes and allow only authorized people to make changes to that particular data.

entry.title: Re: managing Pallets in S4 hana public cloud
entry.content:
Good day @FaisalMaayeh 

Thank you for your question to the community.

Have a look at Handling Units in Cloud Processes & Batch Management for more details.

In summary, you are correct that the Serial Number app in the SH4C is intended for serialised products and not for pallets. If your requirement is to tract supplier assigned pallet IDs and their storage bins, then you should consider a few approaches:

  1. If EWM is in scope, handling units will come serve the purpose. Here you can model each pallet as handling unit, assign the supplier serial number to the HU (either as HU external ID or as an HU characteristic) and then you manage bin assignments through warehouse tasks.
  2. If your HU management is not activated, you could use Batch Management. Please note, if you create a characteristic for Supplier Pallet Serial Number, you can record pallet Ids during goods receipt and track them at batch level.  Handling Units in Cloud Processes
  3. Finally, you can alternatively use Custom Fields and Logic to extend goods receipt document with a custom field for pallet serial number. This will you to capture the supplier’s ID without changing standard material serialisation. Custom Fields and Custom Business Logic

I hope this provides the desired insights.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: SAP MDG-M Custom UI Configuration Performance Comparison and Gains
entry.content:
Introduction

In SAP MDG-M, the standard User Interface (UI) is designed to load the full set of content, ensuring complete visibility but often at the cost of speed and responsiveness. While this “load-everything” approach guarantees access to all data, it also introduces performance bottlenecks that slow down day-to-day work. 

As a team, we explored ways to mitigate these performance challenges and developed a Custom UI solution tailored to our specific needs. But how much of a difference does this new UI make?

To answer this, we conducted structured performance tests, analyzing key factors such as page load times, system resource utilization, and user feedback. This study will reveal the concrete benefits of the new Custom UI compared to standard UIs, providing insights for future optimization efforts.

Background

A good user experience is a key requirement for any user-centric application. As SAP MDG is an enterprise solution involving hundreds of fields per domain, it’s very important to display the relevant role-specific information at each governance process step in a user-friendly manner. This will help the data stewards and data analysts make smart decisions with the help of simple and responsive UIs. 

Standard UIs provide a solid foundation for these processes, ensuring consistency and reliability across the system. As data volumes and usage scenarios expand, however, opportunities emerge to further optimize performance.

User feedback and technical performance analyses highlighted areas where the standard UIs could be further optimized — particularly around load times, resource usage, and navigation flow. To address these opportunities, our team designed a Custom UI solution focused on boosting performance and enhancing usability, while still building on the strengths of the existing framework. 

In this study, we assess the impact of Custom UIs on performance and compare them with existing standard UIs. The goal is to determine the areas where improvements have been achieved.

Test Methodology and Scope

To measure these differences objectively, we conducted rigorous performance tests under identical conditions.

For performance analysis, we focused on the following criteria:
  • Page Load Time: A crucial factor affecting user experience
  • System Resource Utilization: Efficiency in memory (RAM), CPU, and database queries
  • User Feedback: Objective evaluation through surveys and scores

Tests were conducted under predefined conditions using identical datasets. Below are the tools and test conditions used.

Testing Tool:  Http Trace Using

UI Type: Standard UI (BS_MAT_OVP_09H) - Average Load Time: 1789 msn


Figure 1 – Standard UI http trace

UI Type: Custom UI (Z9H_BS_MAT_OVP_09H) - Average Load Time: 858 msn


Figure 2 – Custom UI http trace

System Resource Utilization (Memory, CPU, Database Queries)

UI Type: Standart UI - AT_OVP~BS_MAT_OVP_09


Figure 3 – Standard UI System Resource Utilization

UI Type: Custom UI - P~Z9H_BS_MAT_OVP_09H


Figure 4 – Custom UI System Resource Utilization

The performance metrics above may vary depending on several factors such as the density of data in the database, system resource usage, network speed, and similar elements. Therefore, performance results may differ under varying conditions.

Results and Gains

Our analysis revealed clear benefits that directly strengthen both system efficiency and the user experience. The enhancements not only streamline resource usage but also make the UI more responsive and enjoyable to work with — especially in large-scale data operations

Here’s a summary of the key gains achieved with the Custom UI:
  • Performance Improvement: Noticeably faster page load times, ensuring smoother workflows.
  • Optimized Resource Utilization: Reduced memory and CPU usage, allowing the system to run more efficiently.
  • Higher User Satisfaction: Improved usability and more positive user feedback, reflecting greater engagement.

Thank you for reading,

Best regards.

Ahmet

entry.title: Re: Same short desc & Long desc for different material co...
entry.content:
To your question "Does same short/long description = duplicate material?", not necessarily. In SAP, the material number (MATNR) is the true unique identifier. Descriptions (short/long) are just text fields and can be reused across multiple materials. Generic descriptions like “Bolt” or “Cable” are often reused for different sizes/specs. Different plants or business units may create materials with the same description but different control data (valuation class, base unit, procurement type, etc.).

When you can consider that as a duplication is If all key attributes (material group, base unit, valuation class, procurement type, etc.) are the same, and only the material number differs, then yes—it’s likely a duplicate. Duplicates often arise when materials are created via multiple channels (MM01 manually vs. Data Services migration) without a harmonized governance process.

So if you ask me how to check the duplicates, perform the below steps


Go to MARA/MARC tables. Compare fields like MATKL (Material Group), MEINS (Base Unit), MTART (Material Type), BKLAS (Valuation Class). If many fields match along with identical descriptions, it’s a strong duplicate candidate.

Use “Old Material Number” (MARA-BISMT) if available → Sometimes legacy codes are stored here and can help identify duplicates.

entry.title: Choosing the Right SAP Analytics Tool: Features, Benefits, and Strategy
entry.content:
Introduction : 

Within an organization's data and analytics strategy, SAP provides a portfolio of analytics solutions, including SAP S/4HANA Embedded Analytics, SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC), and SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC), each with a specific function. To assist clients in selecting the best option for their requirements, a comparative analysis of their salient characteristics and advantages is provided below.

SAP S/4HANA Embedded Analytics

Summary: This solution, which is directly integrated into the SAP S/4HANA ERP system, offers real-time analytics on operational data without requiring data replication.

Key Benefits :

  • Operational Reporting in Real Time: Get the most recent information straight from the ERP system.
  • Views of Core Data Services (CDS): For customizable reporting, use virtual data models.
  • Predefined KPIs and Dashboards: Use unconventional content to gain rapid insights.
  • Fiori-Based User Interface: Enhanced user experience through intuitive design.

Benefits:

  • Immediate Decision-Making: Facilitates quick actions based on current data.
  • Simplified Infrastructure: Eliminates the need for separate data warehousing solutions.
  • Seamless Integration: Embedded within the core ERP system, ensuring consistency.

 

SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC)

Summary: A cloud-based platform combining business intelligence, planning, and predictive analytics, SAC connects to various data sources, including SAP and non-SAP systems.

Key Features:

  • Advanced Analytics: Utilize AI-driven insights and predictive modelling.
  • Planning Capabilities: Integrate financial planning and budgeting processes.
  • Collaboration Tools: Facilitate real-time discussions and decision-making.
  • Mobile Accessibility: Access analytics on-the-go through optimized dashboards.

Benefits:

  • Comprehensive Insights: Consolidates data from multiple sources for holistic analysis.
  • Enhanced Forecasting: Improves accuracy in planning and budgeting.
  • Scalability: Cloud infrastructure supports growth and flexibility.

 

SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC)

 Overview: A fully managed SaaS solution that unifies and governs SAP and third-party data, enabling advanced analytics and AI-driven insights across the organization.

Key Features:

  • Data Integration: Connects disparate data sources into a unified platform.
  • AI and ML Capabilities: Leverages machine learning for predictive analytics.
  • Prebuilt Applications: Offers industry-specific solutions and dashboards.
  • Data Governance: Ensures data quality and compliance across the organization.

Benefits:

  • Accelerated Decision-Making: Provides timely insights for informed decisions.
  • Reduced Complexity: Simplifies data management and analytics processes.
  • Enhanced Collaboration: Fosters cross-departmental data sharing and insights.

 

Comparative Study

Recommendation:

  • Choose SAP S/4HANA Embedded Analytics if your primary need is real-time, operational reporting directly within your ERP system, with minimal infrastructure overhead.

  • Opt for SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) when you require advanced analytics, predictive modeling, and planning capabilities across various data sources, with a focus on scalability and collaboration.

  • Consider SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) if your organization seeks a unified platform for data integration, governance, and AI-driven insights, encompassing both SAP and third-party data sources.

Thank you for your time.  Stay connected for further updates on Analytics !

-With Warm Regards :  GIRI

entry.title: Re: Set the batch number to a fixed value for each materi...
entry.content:
Hi Freya,

Based your description, I suggest that you can leverage several BAdIs to meet your requirement.

First is LOBM_AFTER_BATCH_NUMBER_INT, you can use this BAdI to create a new batch number and adapt it. But the limitation is that it only works when the batch number doesn't exist. So you can implement some logics to check if in I_BATCH, the batch number exists. If exists, you need to use BAdI MMIM_GR4XY_PROVIDE_DATA and MMIM_ITEM_PROVIDE_DATA. These BAdIs can help you to change data in goods receipt and material documents. So they can work in the APP MIGO and Post Goods Receipt. You can implement some logics to change the relevant fields' value.

Hope my answer can help you to solve the question.

Best Regards,

Zhehui
